The ILuthCompilerService is to only perform static analysis of source code. One should never execute the source code which is being analyzed. However, for testing purposes it can be useful to see if one's logic for parsing expressions evaluates properly. And so, for testing only, the IEvaluator exists. Again, the ILuthCompilerService should NEVER execute source code which it is analyzing. If one invokes, "_ = editContext.GetViewModelModifier(viewModelKey);". Then a side effect occurs where the view model with the provided viewModelKey, will be marked as a having been modified. After a Post is finished, the text editor service iterates over all 'modified' view models and re-renders them. This behavior is a bit hacky since it requires some amount of 'hidden knowledge'. To get a view model without marking it as modified, use the optional parameter, 'isReadonly' and set it to 'true'. The main reason for making this comment, is that I sometimes assign the result of 'GetViewModelModifier' to discard. When I do this it feels especially hacky, so I want to leave a paper trail of what I mean by that statement. TODO: (2023-06-09) This class is a hacky way to track a cancellation token source per each text editor model. As of this comment, TextEditorModel is a class which is frequently re-constructed with new(). A CancellationTokenSource as a property would therefore not work. One would Cancel() then new() up another CancellationTokenSource and update the property. Yet its possible that instance of TextEditorModel isn't even being used anymore by that point. So a readonly object wrapper which then contains the CancellationTokenSource ensures it doesn't get lost Luthetus.TextEditor.Tests.Basis.TextEditors.Models.Internals.SaveFileHelperTests

TODO: Decide on what folder this class belongs in... ...I'm working on the Quick Actions / Refactor context menu (2024-08-16) and the issue is that, the context menu is populated with menu options from within the ITextEditorEditContext. | But by the time the user picks a context menu option, the text editor may have been edited, thus invalidating any stored Func<Task> that is given for a menu option's onclick. | So, each menu option needs to make a separate Post to the ITextEditorService upon onclick. | But, all of the variables that were created to construct the menu options, during the old post, are still within scope when typing out code for the menu option's onclick if written inline as a lambda function. | So, most importantly this class exists to avoid accidental usage of old text editor state due to the variables being in scope. | But this also probably is nice for readability, and re-usability of the refactor itself. | I don't want a separate function within TextEditorCommandDefaultFunctions because it is a nice separation of concern to keep compiler service refactors in a separate file Luthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.Decorations.Models.TextEditorRegistryWrapLuthetus.TextEditor.RazorLib.TextEditors.Models.Internals.TextEditorRenderBatchValidatedLuthetus.TextEditor.Tests.Basis.Cursors.Models.TextEditorSelectionHelperTests
